prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B14_z7LBG_238225
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B14_z7LBG_238225

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 6.98(+0.12/-0.12) = 6.86-7.10 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 234.63-241.80 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 234.53 - 241.90 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 100 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 4.0e+42 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 8.82 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 8.82/5 = 1.763 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 58.58 min (0.98 hours) including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 25 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 75 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 4.3e11 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 4.3e11 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 0.474 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 6.9. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B14_z7LBG_304384
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B14_z7LBG_304384

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 6.64(+0.120.22) = 6.42-6.76 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 245.04-256.27 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 244.94 - 256.37 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 250 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 1.0e+43 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 23.78 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 23.78mJy/5 = 4.756 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 1.13 hours including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 26 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 224 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 1.3e12 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 1.3e12 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 3.52 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 26.2. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B12_z7LBG_277912

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 6.85(+0.08/-0.08) = 6.77-6.93 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 239.92-244.86 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 239.82-244.96 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 330 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 1.3e+43 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 28.61 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 28.61mJy/5 = 5.722 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 37.55 min (0.63 hours) including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 44 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 286 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 1.7e12 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 1.7e12 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 6.74 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 47.7. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B12_z7LBG_155880
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B12_z7LBG_155880

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 6.70(+0.05/-0.06) = 6.64-6.75 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 245.62-249.15 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 245.52-249.25 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 110 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 4.0e+42 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 9.34 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 9.34 mJy/5 = 1.867 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 40.72 min (0.68 hours) including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 32 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 78 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 4.5e11 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 4.5e11 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 2.59 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 30.6. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B12_z7LBG_277880
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B12_z7LBG_277880

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 6.77(+0.07/-0.08) = 6.69-6.84 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 242.80-247.53 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 242.70-247.63 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 280 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 1.0e+43 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 23.00 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 23.00 mJy/5 = 4.620 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 37.55 min (0.63 hours) including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 26 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 254 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 1.5e12 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 1.5e12 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 14.91 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 113.5. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B12_z7LBG_218467
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B12_z7LBG_218467

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 7.04(+0.10/-0.08) = 6.96-7.14 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 233.85-239.14 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 233.75-239.24 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 53 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 1.8e+42 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 3.88 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 3.88 mJy/5 = 0.777 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 1.19 hours including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 31 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 22 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 1.3e11 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 1.3e11 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 1.58 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 42.5. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B12_z7LBG_61432
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: An spectral scan observation of a z~7 LBG candidate B12_z7LBG_61432

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect 158 micron [CII] line (rest 1900.54 GHz) of this Lyman break galaxy (LBG) at S/N >= 5 as well as detect its rest FIR continuum flux at S/N >= 5. The redshift of this object has not been confirmed by spectroscopy but has been constrained to the photometric redshift of zphot = 7.07(+0.14/-0.10) = 6.97-7.21 by SED-fitting to optical to near-IR data (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Thus, [CII] line is redshifted to 231.86-238.84 GHz, and we would like to search for [CII] line at this frequency range by spectral scan mode. If the [CII] line is located at the edge of this range, it could be truncated. To avoid this, we would like to scan +/-0.1 GHz (i.e., +/- expected line width = +/-100 km/s) wider range 231.76-238.94 GHz. We do not know the [CII] line width of this target, so we assume it is 100 km/s because the recent observation of a z ~ 7 LBG by Maiolino et al.(2015, arXiv:1502.06634) detected a tentative [CII] line of FWHM ~ 100 km/s. Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have FWHM ~ 100 km/s on average. De Looze et al. (2011, MNRAS, 416, 2712) found a [CII] luminosity vs. star formation rate (SFR) (L[CII] - SFR) correlation for local star forming galaxies (see the solid line in Figure 1 in Science Justification (SJ)). Also, Capak et al. (2015) found z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs follow this correlation (Figure 1 in SJ). We assume that our target galaxy follows this correlation. This target galaxy has a total SFR(total) = 52 Msun/yr estimated from SED-fitting to its optical to near-IR fluxes (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS 440, 2810). Using the correlation, this SFR converts to L[CII] = 1.8e+42 erg/s. This translates to the peak line flux density of S[CII] = 3.86 mJy for 100 km/s line velocity width. To detect [CII] line at S/N=5, we request a sensitivity of 1 sigma = 3.86 mJy/5 = 0.772 mJy per pointing (we will cover the entire target by one beam). We input this into "Time Estimate" of ALMA Cycle 3 Observing Tool (OT), using a frequency width of 20 km/s (this resolution is high enough to resolve the 100 km/s [CII] line and can still detect the line even if it was unexpectedly narrower). We obtain 2.43 hours including calibration and overheads. Meanwhile, this target galaxy has SFR(UV) = 31 Msun/yr estimated from its rest UV continuum flux (Bowler et al. 2014). Thus, it has a dust obscured (corresponding to total IR SFR) of SFR(IR) = SFR(total) - SFR(UV) = 21 Msun/yr. Using the Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) equation, this converts to a total IR luminosity of L(IR) = 1.2e11 Lsun. Ota et al.(2014, ApJ, 792, 34) found a z ~ 7 star-forming galaxy has an SED shape similar to those of local dwarf/irregular galaxies. Local dwarf/irregular galaxies have on average dust temperature of 27.6 K and dust emissivity index of 1.5 when their SEDs are fitted by modified black body (MBB) (Skibba et al. 2011, ApJ, 738, 89). So, we assume that the SED of our target (z ~ 7 LBG) can be also modeled by such an MBB. Because integrating this MBB scaled to the peak continuum flux density S(cont) of our target galaxy at 8-1000um gives L(IR) = 1.2e11 Lsun, we obtain S(cont) = 1.67 mJy. Inputting this into the ALMA Cycle 3 OT gives the achieved S/N = 56.3. This is high enough to detect the dust (rest FIR) continuum.

We choose the Dual Polarization FDM mode with 1875 MHz bandwidth to cover a wide range of continuum to achieve the highest sensitivity to the continuum. Also, in our ALMA Cycle 0 observation, we detected the possible [CII] line with a width of 63 km/s at S/N=3 and the highest possible resolution of 40 km/s with the TDM mode (Ota et al. ApJ, 792, 34). Also, Capak et al. (2015, arXiv:1503.07596) detected 11 z ~ 5.2-5.7 LBGs in [CII] and they have a range of line width ~ 20-162 km/s. Thus, there is a possibility that the [CII] line width is much narrower than 100 km/s, which we assume in this OT. This will possibly cause the lower S/N detections. Recent theoretical models (e.g., Vallini et al. 2013, MNRAS, 433, 1567) simulating the [CII] line of high-z galaxies also suggest that [CII] emission would likely come from more external accreting/satellite "clumps" of neutral gas as molecular clouds in the central parts of primordial galaxies are rapidly disrupted by stellar feedback. If [CII] line arises from such clumps, it could be very narrow. To secure the detection of the [CII] line at the S/N as high as possible even if it was very narrow, we would like to obtain the spectral resolution as high as possible with the FDM mode. To reduce the data rate, we use averaging = 2.

This target galaxy has a spatial size of < ~1.0" (< ~5 kpc at its photometric redshift) in rest UV continuum emission image (Bowler et al. 2014, MNRAS, 440, 2810). Hence, we request the largest angular scale of 1.0". Also, we would like to use an angular resolution = 1.0" to cover all the fluxes of the [CII] line and FIR continuum with one synthesized beam in case they are as extended as the galaxy size in UV continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Probing gas and dust of galaxies to earlier Universe including epoch of reionization (EoR) at z > 6 is key to revealing how galaxies formed and reionization progressed over cosmic time. 158 um [CII], the strongest cooling line of interstellar medium (ISM) and useful star formation rate (SFR) indicator, and dust continuum have been detected to study gas/dust of various galaxies from local to high-z. Of them, normal star-forming (SF) galaxies have been detected in [CII]/dust up to z~5.7 and observed to follow a local tight [CII] luminosity - SFR correlation, but neither robust detection nor such correlation has been reported at z > 6. This can be because (1) only the small number of EoR SF galaxies relatively fainter than z < 6 ones have been observed and/or (2) because states of gas/dust in z > 6 EoR SF galaxies are completely different from those of z < 6 ones. Here we propose to observe [CII] & dust continua of eight z~6.6-7.1 brightest EoR SF galaxies found in recent large area surveys to probe a sample large and bright enough to clarify (1) & (2). We will also investigate relation between high-z and other galaxy populations, obscured SFR, dynamics & state of ISM of EoR galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: CODE: 2012.1.00374.S, TITLE: The [CII] Line Study of Star-forming Galaxies in the Epoch of Cosmic Reionization; PI: Kazuaki Ota CODE: 2011.0.00767.S, TITLE: The [CII] Line Study of a Star-forming Galaxy in the Epoch of Cosmic Reionization, PI: Kazuaki Ota
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Cambridge, University of
